column5: So you can buy eggs in Canada, they are available pretty much everywhere...just sayin

Yes... why would anyone bring eggs to CAN ? Just the aspect of keeping them at the right temps and not cracking would keep me away. Seems to me that fresh "eggs" are not perfect food for "roughing it".
Really? Then why do you even bother with 5 dollars worth of eggs from the U.S. when you can just eliminate the hassle and buy your eggs in Canada??????
My guess would be so as not to have to stop for groceries. The only stops I ever make are for gas/bathroom, border crossing, and one time a moose.
For our group, not buying eggs in Canada is a matter of: Cost Convenience Time Not saying our way of doing things is right for everyone. However for us it works out nicely. Happy New Year everyone.

Question on eggs and potatoes in Canada........ Are sunny side up eggs allowed or are just scrambled eggs legal in Canada and what about home fries . . . . OH, I almost forgot............do you have to only use Canadian Bacon in Canada..... LOL
You can bring your eggs into Canada ,but don't try to take our Cadbury Easter Creme eggs back home with you!!
Not that they'd make it all the way home anyway.

Will be coming into Canada over the upcoming holiday so wondering if we can bring eggs across the border and if so are there any restrictions or rules related to bringing them across? Thanks in advance.
they won't ask so why tell them?
Last i seen the only state that still had a restriction was eggs from Indiana. I would bet that thay have been ok'd by now.

Indiana is all that I could find as being states from which poultry products are not allowed. When buying eggs for our trips, I always made sure the carton shows what state the eggs came from. Took a bit more work, but I just did not want the hassle of having to throw the eggs away at the border any buying more in Fort Frances. Sure the border guards might not ask you specifically about eggs - but if they decide to search the car for whatever reason and see eggs from Indiana, don't you think they search the vehicle & boat even more closely?
Sorry--I can't live my life that way--intentionally breaking the law and then saying "Sorry" if I get caught. Especially over $5 worth of groceries.

I just checked with the CBSA food search for Gallus domesticus / chicken eggs. even from Indiana they are approved. Max amount allowed in 30 doz. you can expect to pay duty on more than 2 doz eggs per person. That being said. Things can change over night and the web sight may not be up dates right away. There could be an emergency flash sent to the CBSA officers at all crossings. And the site not be updated.

Summary of Requirements Import Details for Requirement : 45820 Version : 22 HS Description : 040721 04 Dairy produce; birds' eggs; natural honey; edible products of animal origin, not elsewhere specified or included 07 Birds' eggs, in shell, fresh, preserved or cooked 21 Other fresh eggs: Of fowls of the species Gallus domesticus OGD Extension : 027103 0271 Shell eggs from chicken 03 Grade A - large Origin : UIN US United States UIN Indiana End Use : 46 46 Travellers & Personal use and not for resale or distribution Recommendations to CBSA/Documentation and Registration Requirements Approved
Say, are potatoes allowed to be brought over into Canada? Bill
Pretty sure only if packed in worm bedding, no dirt. I probably just made that up.

Here is what I discovered: Commercially packaged potatoes from Minnesota anyway! Summary of Requirements Import Details for Requirement : 53774 Version : 2 HS Description : 070190 07 Edible vegetables and certain roots and tubers 01 Potatoes, fresh or chilled 90 Other OGD Extension : 300000 3000 Potato - tuber (fresh) Origin : UMN US United States UMN Minnesota End Use : 46 46 Travellers & Personal use and not for resale or distribution Miscellaneous : 756 756 4.5 kg or less, commercially packaged Recommendations to CBSA/Documentation and Registration Requirements Approved Importer / Broker Instructions DOCUMENTATION INSTRUCTIONS The certification of state of origin is not required and no other import documentation requirements apply. CONDITIONS OF IMPORT The import of 4.5 kg (10 lbs) or less per conveyance of packaged potatoes for human consumption is permitted when commercially packaged and labelled as meeting U.S. no.1 grade. Shipment of fresh fruits and vegetables must consist of 15 packages or less with a weight not exceeding 250 kg (551 lb). ADDITIONAL INSTRUCTIONS All purple and blue skinned potato varieties susceptible to potato wart (Synchytrium endobioticum (Schilb.) Perc.) are PROHIBITED entry into the province of Newfoundland and Labrador; the following varieties are resistant, and can be imported: AC Blue Pride, AC Domino, Blue Mac and Brigus. Moreover, potatoes shipped to that province must be free of the Colorado potato beetle (Leptinotarsa decemlineata).
